text: [Music]
what I want to talk to you about is what
we can learn from studying the genomes
of living people and extinct humans but
before doing that I just briefly want to
remind you about what you already know
that are genomes our genetic material
are stored in almost all cells in our
bodies on chromosomes in the form of DNA
which is this famous double helical
molecule and the genetic information is
contained in the form of the sequence of
four bases abbreviated with the letters
a t c and e and the information is there
twice one on each strand which is
important because when new cells are
formed these strands come apart new
strands are synthesized with the old on
as template in an almost perfect
process but nothing of course in nature
is totally perfect so sometimes an error
is made and a wrong letter is built in
and we can then see the result of such
mutations when we compare DNA sequences
Among Us here in the room for example if
we compare my genome to a genome of you
approximately every 1200 1300 letters
will differ between us and these
mutations accumulate approximately as a
function of time so if we add in a
chimpanzee here we will see more
differences approximately one letter in
a 100 will differ to a
chimpanzee and if you're then interested
in the history of a piece of DNA or the
whole genomes you can reconstruct the
history of the DNA with those
differences You observe and generally we
depict our ideas about this history in
the form of trees like this in this case
it's very simple the two two human DNA
sequences go back to a common ancestor
quite recently further back is there one
shared with the chimpan sees and because
these mutations happen approximately as
a function of time you can transform
these differences to estimates of time
where the two humans typically will
share a common ancestor about half a
million years ago and with the chimpan
it will be in the order of 5 million
years ago so what has now happened in
last few years is that there have come
Technologies around that allow you to
see many many pieces of DNA very quickly
so we can now in a matter of hours
determine a whole Human Genome each of
us of course contains two human genomes
one from our mothers and one from our
fathers and they are around three
billion such letters long and we will
find that the two genomes in me your one
Genome of mine with one of you will have
about three million differences in the
order of that
and what you can then also begin to do
is to say how are these genetic
differences distributed across the world
and if you do that you find a certain
amount of genetic variation in Africa
and if you look outside Africa you
actually find less genetic variation
this is surprising of course because in
the order of 6 to8 times fewer people
live in Africa than outside Africa yet
the people outs inside Africa more
genetic
variation moreover almost all these
genetic variants we see outside Africa
have closely related DNA sequences that
you find inside Africa but if you look
in Africa there's a component of the
genetic variation that have no close
relatives
outside so a model to explain this is
that a part of the African variation but
not all of it have gone out and
colonized the rest of the
world and together with then methods to
date these genetic differences this has
led to the Insight that modern humans
humans that are essentially
indistinguishable from you and me
evolved in Africa quite recently between
100 and 200,000 years ago and later bit
between 100 and 50,000 years ago or so
went out of Africa to colonize the rest
of the world so what I often like to say
is that from a genomic perspective then
we are all AF Africans we either live
inside Africa today or in quite recent
Exile another sort of consequence of
this recent origin of modern humans is
that genetic variants are generally
distributed widely in the world at many
places and they tend to vary as
gradients from a bird's eyes perspective
at least and since there are many
genetic variants and they have different
such gradients this means that if we
determine a DNA sequence a genome from a
one individual we can quite accurately
estimate where that person comes from
provided that its parents or
grandparents haven't moved around too
much but does this then mean as many
people tend to think that there are huge
genetic differences between groups of
people on different continents for
example well we can begin to ask those
questions also there is for example a
project that's underway to sequence
thousand individuals their genomes from
different parts of the world they've
sequenced 185 Africans from two
populations in Africa the sequence
approximately equally many people in
Europe and in China and we can begin to
say how much variance do we find how
many letters that vary in at least one
of those individual sequence and it's a
lot 38 million variable positions but we
can then then ask are there any absolute
differences between Africans and
non-africans perhaps the biggest
difference most of us would imagine
existed and with absolute difference and
I mean a difference where people inside
Africa at a certain Position will all
individuals 100% have one letter and
everybody outside Africa has another
letter and the answer to that among
those millions of differences is that
there is not a single such position
this may be surprising maybe a single
individual is misclassified or so so we
can relax the criteria bit and say how
many positions do we find where 95% of
people in Africa have one variant 95%
another variant and the number of that
are
12 so this is very surprising it means
that when we look at people and see a
person from Africa and a person from
Europe or Asia we cannot for a single
position in the genome with 100 %
accuracy predict what the person would
carry and only for 12 positions can we
hope to be 95% right this may be
surprising because we can of course look
at these people and quite easily say
where they or their ancestors came from
so what this means then is that those
traits we then look at and so readily
see facial features skin color hair
structure are not determined by single
genes with big effects but are
determined by many different genetic
variants that simply vary in frequency
between different parts of the
world there is another thing with those
traits that we so easily observe in each
other that I think is worthwhile to
consider and that is that in a very
literal sense they're really on the
surface of our bodies they are what we
just said facial features hair structure
skin color there are also a number of
features that vary between continents
like that that have to do with how we
metabolize food that we ingest or that
have to do with how our immune system
deal with microbes that try to invade
our bodies but so those are all parts of
our bodies where we very directly
interact with the environment in a
direct confrontation if you like so it's
easy to imagine how particularly those
parts of our bodies were quickly
influenced by selection from the
environment and shifted frequencies of
gen that are involved in them but if you
look on other parts of our bodies where
we don't directly interact with the
environment our kidneys our liers our
hearts there is no way to say by just
looking at these organs where in the
world they would come from
right so there's another interesting
thing that comes from this realization
that humans have a recent common origin
in Africa and that is that when that
humans emerg around 100,000 years ago or
so they were not alone on the planet
there were other forms of humans around
most famously perhaps neandertals these
robust forms of humans compared to the
left here with a modern human skeleton
on the right that existed in Western
Asia and Europe since several hundred
thousands of years so an interesting
question is what happened when we met
what happened to the
neander and to begin to answer that
question questions my research group
since over 25 years now work on methods
to extract DNA from remains of Neals and
extinct animals that are tens of
thousands of years old so this involves
a lot of technical issues in how you
extract the DNA how you convert it to a
form you can sequence you have to work
very carefully to avoid contamination of
the experiments with DNA from
yourself and this then in conjunction
with these methods that allow very many
DNA molecules to be sequenced very
rapidly allowed us last year to present
the first version of The neander genome
so that any one of you can now look on
the internet on the neander genome or at
least on the 55% of it that we've been
able to reconstruct so far and you can
begin to compare it to the genomes of
people who live
today and one question that you may then
want to ask ask is what happened when we
met did we mix or not and the way to ask
that question is to look at the neander
that comes from southern Europe and
compare it to genomes of people who live
today so we then look to do this at
pairs of individuals starting with two
Africans looking at the two African
genomes finding places where they differ
from each other and in each case ask
what is an Nal like does it match one
African or the other African
we would expect it to be no difference
because neander were never in Africa
they should be equal not have no reason
to be closer to one African than another
African and that's indeed the case
statistically speaking there is no
difference in how often the neon matches
one African or the other but this is
different if we now look at a European
individual and an African then
significantly more often does a neand
match European rather than the African
the same is true if we look in a Chinese
individual versus an African the neand
will match the Chinese individual more
often this may also be surprising
because the Neons were never in China so
the model we've proposed to explain this
is that when modern humans came out of
Africa sometime after 100,000 years ago
they met NE
underalls presumably they did so first
in the Middle East where the were
under's living if one then mixed with
each other there then those modern
humans that became the ancestors of
everyone outside Africa carried with
them this neeral component in their
genome to the rest of the world so that
today then people living outside Africa
have about 2 and a half% of their DNA
from
neandertals so having now neander at
hand as a reference point and having the
Technologies to look at ancient remains
and extract the DNA we can be begin to
apply them elsewhere in the world and
the first place we've done that is in
southern Siberia in the alai mountains
at a place called denissa a cave site in
this mountain here where archaeologists
in 2008 found a tiny little piece of
bone this is a copy of it that they
realized came from the last fallons of a
little finger of a pinky of a human
and it was well enough preserved so we
could determine the DNA from this
individual even to a greater extent than
for the neandertals actually and start
relating it to the neander genome and to
people today and we found that this
individual shared a common origin for
its DNA sequences with neand around
640,000 years ago and further back
800,000 years ago is there a common
origin with present day humans
so this individual comes from a
population that shares An Origin with
the under but far back and then have a
long independent history we call this
group of humans that we then describe
for the first time from this tiny tiny
little piece of bone for denans after
this place where they were first
described so we can then ask for
the the same things as for the nandal
did they mix with ancestors of any the
present day people if we ask that
question and compare the denivan genome
to people around the world we
surprisingly find no evidence of denan
DNA in any people
living even close to Siberia today but
we do find it in Papa new guini and in
other Islands in melanesia and the
Pacific so this presumably means that
these denans have been more widespread
in the past since we don't think that
the ancestors of melanesians were ever
in Siberia so from studying these
genomes of extinct humans we're
beginning to arrive at a picture of what
the world looked like when modern humans
started coming out of Africa in the west
there were neandertals in the East there
were the Nissans maybe other forms of
humans too that we have not yet
described we don't know quite where the
border between these people were but we
know that in southern Siberia there were
both neander and den at least at some
times in the past then modern humans
emerge somewhere in Africa Come Out of
Africa presumably in the Middle East
they meet the underalls mix with them
continue to spread over the world and
somewhere in Southeast Asia they meet
the Nissans mix with them and continue
on out into the Pacific and then these
earli forms of humans disappear but they
live on a little bit today in some of us
in that people outside Africa have 2 and
a half% of their DNA from the underalls
and people in melanesia actually have an
additional 5% approximately from the
denans does this then mean that there is
after all some absolute difference
between people outside Africa and inside
Africa in that people outside Africa
have this old component in their genome
from these extinct forms of humans
whereas Africans do not well I don't
think that is the case presumably modern
humus emerged somewhere in Africa they
spread across Africa also of course and
there were older earlier forms of humans
there and since we mixed elsewhere I'm
pretty sure that one day when we will
perhaps have a genome of also these
earlier forms in Africa we will find
that they have also mixed with early
modern humans in
Africa so to sum up what have we learned
from studying genomes of present day
humans and or extinct hum humans learned
perhaps many things but I one thing that
I find sort of important to mention is
that I think a lesson is that we have
always mixed we're mixed with these
earlier forms of humans wherever we met
them and we're mixed with each other
ever since thank you for your
